Intellectual disability vs. Learning Disability

  • Intellectual disability implies global developmental impairment. Language, visual motor skills, integration and problems-solving skills, and functional living skills are all impaired (IQ <70; 2.2 % of population). Both a functional disability and low IQ must be demonstrated to give this dx.
  • Learning disability is defined by normal overall development but difficulties in acquiring or performing specific skills (e.g. reading or arithmetic). Specific processing difficulties are identifiable, difficulties are not associated with limited exposure, language difference, emotional issues or sensory deficit. IQ is normal (>70).

IEP (Individual Education Plan) v 504

IEP

  • IDEA requires all schools to provide a free and appropriate education to all students, regardless of disability
  • An evaluation must be completed to determine if child qualifies for services (for ex, special education, speech therapy, psychological services)
  • To qualify, must have a disability AND it must be educationally handicapping (can‚Äôt just have ADHD and automatically get an IEP)
  • An Individual Education Plan (IEP) is developed documenting remedial services to be provided and annual goals to be achieved
  • Includes many specific procedures and safeguards that must be followed in developing and reviewing IEPs

504 Plan

  • It is not necessary for a child‚Äôs disability to be educationally handicapping in order to qualify for the protections under Section 504.
  • 504 Plan provides for accommodations, and modifications to ensure equal access to education, for example:
    • wheelchair access/use of the elevator
    • Classroom accommodations for children with ADHD
    • Extended time for children with seizures
    • Extra set of books for children with ataxia

Memory deficits

  • Complaints of ‚Äúpoor memory‚Äù are ubiquitous
  • Very few children have specific and isolated memory deficits
  • Most ‚Äúmemory‚Äù problems turn out to be:
    • Decreased overall ability
    • Learning disability
    • Inattention / ADHD
    • Poor behavioral control
  • Ask parents to tell you what they are observing, rather than giving it a name (‚Äúmemory problems‚Äù). ‚ÄúTell me what you notice XXX doing‚Äù
    • She remembers how to read a word at the top of the page, but doesn‚Äôt remember what word it is at the bottom of the page (NOT a memory problem; often a complaint in reading disabled children)
    • He doesn‚Äôt remember to bring home his homework or to do the chores I tell him to complete (NOT a memory problem: often a complaint in children with attention disorder and behavioral problems)
    • She doesn‚Äôt remember to turn in her homework (NOT a memory problem; can be associated with ADHD)
    • He doesn‚Äôt remember what the other kids can remember; he doesn‚Äôt know his address, or his birthday and he can‚Äôt figure out what to do if there are no Frosted Cheerios at the grocery store (NOT a memory problem; can be an intellectual disability).
    • She doesn‚Äôt remember what she reads (?can she read fluently?) No (NOT a memory problem, often associated with a reading disorder)
  • Isolated memory disorders affect memory specifically and pervasively. Children with memory disorders not only cannot remember to bring home their homework, but they don‚Äôt know (for example) what they ate for breakfast, the plot of a movie if they have to stop the movie to eat, are unfamiliar with the plot of a story that has been read to them, cannot recall discussions with their friends, they don‚Äôt have a sense of familiarity once the situation or story has been described. They may not recognize as familiar people whom they have previously met. It may not be consistent, but the memory issues impinge upon life in general (e.g. these children lack a consistent sense of the continuity of experience) and is NOT isolated to school.

Evaluation of Global Developmental Delay

Definition of GDD: there must be significant impairment (>2 SD from norm) in at least 2 of the following areas: Motor (gross or fine), speech and language, cognition, personal-social, activities of daily living. If ‚â•2 areas are not involved, or the impairment is not significant, the GDD/ID diagnosis is not applicable and evaluation should not be undertaken. There are different recommended evaluations for isolated language disorders and autistic spectrum disorders.

Causes of GDD by Etiology

Diagnosis is only made in about 50% of cases, with 75% of these due to the top 3 etiologies. Diagnosis is more likely to be found with the presence of microcephaly, an abnormal prenatal or perinatal history, an abnormal neurological examination, or the absence of coexisting autistic features.

  • Genetic Syndrome or Chromosomal Abnormality (40% of these were non-syndromic)
    • Intrapartum Hypoxic-ischemic injury
    • Cerebral Dysgenesis
    • Early Severe Psychosocial Deprivation
    • Antenatal Toxin Exposure (alcohol or multidrug)

Yield of testing:

  • History and physical (20%)
  • Brain MRI without contrast (14% as screening, 55% with indications)
  • Microarray with reflex 5 cell karyotype if negative (8% as screening, 10% with indications)
  • Fragile X (2.6% in boys and girls as screening, 7.6% with indications)
  • MeCP2 in girls (1.5% in girls with mod/severe GDD/ID)
  • Metabolic testing (0.2% as screening, 5% with indications)
  • EEG (1% as screening)
  • Thyroid testing (0% if newborn screening done, 4% if no screening or other indications)

Overall yield increases with increasing severity of developmental delays.
